disability.title: How to Cope with Physical Limitations
disability.description: This article explores how physical limitations affect emotional well-being, highlighting how cognitive distortions shape our sense of capability. Through the story of Anna—who faced depression after her husband’s disability—it traces a path toward emotional recovery using Cognitive Behavioral Therapy and a reevaluation of life values. The article closes by shifting the focus from limitations to possibilities, inviting readers to rethink what happiness and self-realization can look like.

texts: Physical limitations are often seen as problems that feel undeniably “real.”
People who face various limitations due to age or disability—for instance, after an amputation—often fear that this will limit their capacity for happiness.
Disability is an enormous stressor—especially when it happens suddenly, as after a road accident.
In that moment a person confronts loss: a spinal fracture, for example, may mean they can no longer walk.
Everyday life—the familiar picture of the world—can shatter in an instant, replaced by pain, fear, and confusion.
Adapting to new life circumstances comes with a range of emotions and states that psychologists often describe in stages such as denial, depression, acceptance, and so on.
Some people may get “stuck” in one stage for years, while others may “skip” certain stages.
Alongside each person’s unique way of perceiving their limitations, much also depends on loved ones, the support available, and other factors.
Friends and family typically respond with understanding and compassion, which seems appropriate. However, such support can, at times, have the opposite effect.
Emotional suffering is often fueled less by the physical limitations themselves and more by cognitive distortions.
In such cases, compassion can unintentionally intensify self-pity and despair, reinforcing the belief that a person with a disability is destined to experience less joy and satisfaction than others.
Conversely, when a person and their loved ones learn to correct distorted thinking, they often regain a fuller, more joyful emotional life.
Consider Anna, a 35-year-old married mother of two, who began experiencing symptoms of depression around the time her husband’s right leg was paralyzed due to a spinal injury.
For five years she sought relief from her growing despair—through outpatient and inpatient care, antidepressants, and electroconvulsive therapy—without success.
By the time Anna turned to a CBT therapist, she was in a severe depression and believed her problems were unsolvable.
Through tears she described the disappointment she felt trying to cope with her husband’s reduced mobility: “Every time I see other couples doing things we can’t, I feel unbearably sad.
I watch families who walk together, travel, ride bikes—and it hurts. For us, doing any of that would be incredibly difficult.
And they treat it as natural and ordinary, just like we used to. I wish we could do the same, but we can’t anymore.”
Of course, we can’t deny that Anna and Roman’s problem is real: there truly are many things they can no longer do that most of us can.
The same can be said of many older adults, as well as people who are blind or deaf, people with amputations, and many others with physical limitations.
In fact, if you think about it, all of us have some limitations. Does that mean we should all be profoundly unhappy?

quote.text: There are many things in life far worse than having no arms and no legs. Fear is one of them. You can’t live a full life if every decision is driven by fear.
quote.author: Nick Vujicic

test.question: Which cognitive distortion was most prominent in Anna’s thinking?

texts: Indeed, the distortion driving Anna’s suffering and depression was the mental filter.
She fixated on what was unavailable to her, while overlooking many possibilities for shared activities with her husband. This explains her sense of emptiness and joylessness.
The solution turned out to be surprisingly simple: together with her therapist, they made a list of everything Anna and Roman could do together.
Instead of focusing only on what they couldn’t do, they began to notice opportunities for shared time. Let’s look at their dialogue:
So, Anna, what do you and your husband do—or could you do—together?
Well, we still enjoy each other’s company. We go out to dinner, and we’re a big source of support for one another.
Wonderful. What else?
Sometimes we drive around the city or take short trips out of town, play board games, watch movies, read and discuss books, invite friends over, and cook together.
See? In less than a minute you’ve listed five things you can do together. Suppose I gave you homework to continue the list before our next session—how many more items do you think you could add?
I think a lot. I could probably come up with things we’ve never tried before. Maybe something unusual—like a tandem skydive.
Exactly. You could certainly add more adventurous ideas. Keep in mind that you and your husband might be able to do many of the things you dismissed as impossible.

For example, you said you can’t go to the seaside and walk the beach, and you mentioned how much you’d like to swim. What if you planned a trip and chose a quieter place so you wouldn’t feel self-conscious?
If I were at the beach and saw you and Roman, his physical disability wouldn’t bother me in the least. What do you think?
I’m surprised, but that thought doesn’t feel impossible anymore. It actually seems realistic—and I feel a surge of energy and inspiration.
Some people may doubt that such a difficult problem can be addressed—or that depression like Anna’s could lift after working with thoughts and beliefs.
Nevertheless, by the end of therapy Anna reported that the negative emotions had fully subsided and said she felt better than she had in years.
To maintain progress, she will of course need to keep working—challenging thoughts and reshaping thinking habits—but she’s willing and motivated, which is crucial in treating depression.

It’s important to understand that we do not minimize physical limitations—far from it. Rather, we recognize how vital it is, in these difficult circumstances, to learn to focus on what you can do instead of what you can’t.
For example, imagine you very much want to fly to the Moon.
If you constantly dwell on how unlikely it is—since you’re not an astronaut, your health isn’t perfect, you don’t have the funds, you’re not that young anymore—you’ll likely feel deeply discouraged.
And yet there are many other things you can do. By focusing on them, you’ll feel happier.

disease.title: Depression and a Terminal Diagnosis
disease.description: This article examines the emotional and psychological challenges people face after receiving a serious diagnosis, highlighting how hard it can be to convey these experiences to people who are healthy. It tells the story of Olga, whose life changed abruptly after a suspected cancer diagnosis, and how she grappled with depression and loss of meaning through work with a psychologist. In the end, Olga recognizes her inherent self-worth and the importance of small accomplishments, which helps restore her self-esteem and shift her emotional state despite physical suffering.

texts: What happens to a person who learns they have a severe, possibly terminal illness? Many people face trials like these, yet explaining to someone healthy what they feel can be extremely difficult.
Stories of people confronting serious illness often form the basis of novels or films. On screen such plots may take on comedic tones, but in real life everything is far more complex.
Regardless of a disease’s severity or duration, a “death sentence” can feel like an explosion or a bolt of lightning.
A person who receives a terminal diagnosis may develop reactive depression — a rapidly developing mental health condition arising in response to traumatic events or severe stress.
In this state a person may experience fear, anxiety, apathy toward their surroundings, low mood, fatigue, self-doubt, suicidal thoughts, and disturbances in sleep and appetite.
Many illnesses radically change one’s way of life. Someone who was once healthy and active, who loved travel and the outdoors, can become bedridden overnight.
In such a state, they may be unable to get to the bathroom or take a shower without help, let alone go for a simple walk.
Moreover, realizing how much time and effort loved ones spend on caregiving can make a person feel like a burden.

quote.text: Your illness does not define you. Your strength and courage in facing it are what define you.
quote.author: Jules Renard

texts: Olga was 39 when her life changed dramatically due to a suspected cancer diagnosis.
Life seemed to stop: she felt cut off from her familiar reality. All her previous fears and worries felt small compared to the terror that suddenly descended.
When the worst fears were confirmed, it hit Olga and her family like a blast.
In the months that followed, physical weakness pushed her into even deeper despair.
What made things hardest was not only the physical discomfort of illness and chemotherapy, but having to give up activities that mattered deeply to her.
Olga could no longer manage the household as before (her husband took over those tasks); she had to step back from her favorite work, hobbies, and long walks with friends.
Given the reality of Olga’s challenges, should her depression be considered inevitable?
In therapy, automatic thoughts and negative beliefs that troubled her came to light:
I’m not contributing to society
I’m not achieving anything in my career
I can’t take part in active leisure
I’ve become a burden to my husband
These thoughts triggered sadness, anger, disappointment, and guilt — similar to the thoughts of physically healthy people who experience depression.
Her depression was driven less by the tumor itself and more by a negative stance that undermined her sense of worth. By tying her value to achievements, Olga set herself up for suffering.
For her, cancer seemed to say: “Your time is up! You’re worth nothing now!”

Together with her psychologist, Olga plotted a graph of her personal “worth” from birth through an estimated end of life — and saw that her inherent value remained steady at about 85% on an arbitrary scale from 0 to 100.
The psychologist then suggested she rate her productivity over the same time span.
She drew a curve showing low productivity in childhood, a peak in adulthood, and a decline up to the present moment.
This led to two insights. First, even when illness reduced her productivity, she was still contributing to herself and her family through many small, meaningful actions.
Only all-or-nothing thinking could push her to conclude that her contribution was zero.
Second — and even more important — she realized her personal worth had been constant and resilient; it was a given, independent of achievements.
This understanding showed her she didn’t need to “earn” her human value, and that even in a weakened state she remained just as worthy.

Recognizing this significantly reduced her depressive symptoms. It didn’t remove the tumor, pain, or physical suffering, but it restored her wounded self-esteem and substantially shifted her emotional state.

quote.text: Illness cannot steal your hope unless you let it.
quote.author: Nick Vujicic

distortions.title: Reframing Your Thoughts: Easing Depression by Understanding Cognitive Distortions
distortions.description: This article explains how cognitive distortions contribute to the onset and maintenance of depression—and why understanding these mechanisms matters. We offer practical ways to spot and shift negative thinking patterns that can improve how you feel. By looking more closely at cognitive distortions, you take an important step toward healing and strengthening your mental health.

texts: In previous chapters, we discussed how common depressive symptoms are and how they affect daily life. You may have wondered: Why do I feel so bad? Why does the future seem hopeless? Let’s look for answers together.

Cognitive Behavioral Therapy has greatly advanced our understanding of depression. We now know that negative emotions often arise from distorted, pessimistic views of oneself, the world, and the future.
During depression, attention is tuned to the negative: you notice setbacks more, interpret neutral events in unfavorable ways, and downplay or overlook the positive.

quote.text: The greatest discovery of my generation is that a human being can alter their life by altering their attitudes of mind.
quote.author: William James

texts: At the core of depression, you’ll almost always find entrenched negative beliefs and distorted thinking styles.
These irrational thoughts can be grouped into categories known as “cognitive distortions.”
Cognitive distortions show up in many ways. For example:

A person draws sweeping conclusions from single events: one mistake is taken as proof of total incompetence; one setback as a sign that success is impossible. “Nothing will work out for me,” “I’m incapable.” These are common thoughts in depression.

People also lean toward gloomy predictions, convincing themselves in advance that the future will inevitably be bad. “I tried therapy and it didn’t help—so nothing ever will,” “I’ll always be alone and unhappy.”
With an inner dialogue like this, it’s hard to sustain hope or a stable mood.
Here’s the encouraging part: your thoughts can be a key to relief. By learning to notice and shift negative beliefs, you can influence your mood and overall state.

test.question: Which option best describes “cognitive distortions” in the context of depression?
answers: A psychological condition that cannot be changed
Positive thinking patterns that help with depression
Irrational beliefs and thoughts that worsen depressive states

texts: It’s important to notice your irrational thoughts and identify which cognitive distortions they reflect.
This helps you catch unhelpful patterns early, before they take root.
There are many distortions, and we’ve gathered the key ones on a dedicated page in the Automatic Thoughts Diary.
We recommend visiting that section to review each distortion in more detail—adding everything here would be too much for this page.
Read the descriptions and sample dialogues that show how these distortions play out in real life.
See whether similar beliefs show up in your own thinking, and begin gently replacing them with more realistic, supportive alternatives.
Because cognitive distortions are so central, in the next chapters we’ll explore the most common ones in depth.
